ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provided (1) an overview of the rise of print/material culture and new media in the 17th century, and the major polemics and 'querelles' that accompagnied this change, through a (re)examination of more well-known texts and a consideration of less canonincal texts that nevertheless were bestellers in their time ; (2) an introduction to the main tools and theoretical stakes of the Digital Humanities (namely TEI and interface design) through a mini-digital edition project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was well organized and clearly structure. Occasionally, the amount of secondary/critical reading seemed unweildly and detracted from the ability to discuss primary texts in detail.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I would highly recommend this course. It provides a fresh approach to a literature that can often seem uninteresting to non-specialists, and the theoretical questions raised by 17th-century texts and problematics have a great relevance to other centuries (especially the 18th and 19th).
